stream_context.summary: Kaze continues polishing a space/arcade-themed level for the upcoming RTYI demo: performance checks on real N64 hardware, debugging a bridge/texture-alpha rendering issue across emulators, fixing an overpowered lens flare, and implementing key gameplay tech (low-gravity volumes, animated/lighting platforms, and a new warp animation). He also discusses a serious long-term legal/business idea: releasing a non-Nintendo-IP version of the game on Steam via recomp/asset swap, and why demos/playtesting matter.
stream_context.significance_reason: Several interview-relevant decisions land in one stream (Steam-safe original-IP counterpart, replacing/rewriting remaining Nintendo code, and a concrete engine-side change to warp behavior by removing Mario transparency). The rest is substantial but still mid-production debugging and feature implementation rather than a public milestone like a demo drop.

findings.summary: Kaze floats a plan to ship RTYI as-is, but also potentially release a second version that is ~90% the same content with all Nintendo IP replaced by original characters/assets (and some mechanical changes), so they can legally own and sell it (e.g., on Steam via recomp).

He acknowledges there is still original Nintendo code left in the project, but says he intends to replace it—partly for legal cleanliness, but also because he views much of the original code as inefficient and hard to work with.
findings.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.

findings.summary: A warp effect broke rendering because Mario transparency interacts badly with their materials/pipeline; Kaze decides to disable Mario’s transparency capability entirely and replace the fade-out with a scale-based animation (Mario “scales into the ground”), avoiding the transparency system and extra processing flags.

Performance on the space/arcade level is tested (including on real N64). Kaze argues limiting FPS (e.g., to 30) can feel better/mask drops; he sees occasional dips below 30 when viewing the whole level, but considers it acceptable and comparable to worst-case vanilla SM64 moments.

He hits a confusing bridge visibility/solidity/rendering problem and suspects emulator-specific behavior; he notes the issue resembles a known vanilla SM64 bug and also implies some behavior differs depending on emulator accuracy (he references “plus64” vs a more accurate emulator).

Lens flare intensity wouldn’t respond to parameter changes; the root cause was editing the wrong instance/config because the team built levels in reverse order, leading to a mismatch in what data he thought he was changing.
findings.quote: This is unbelievable. Because I made the levels in reverse order.

findings.summary: He outlines a core RTYI difficulty philosophy: he likes extremely hard optional endgame challenges, but recognizes players often stumble into them early and then blame the whole game; he wants to gate or prevent accidental encounters.

Kaze describes his level-building workflow as an iterative “toybox” method: implement actors/mechanics first, block out platforming, then rearrange and test repeatedly—keeping what feels fun and discarding what doesn’t—followed by polish.
He implements a low-gravity zone as a placeable volume and is pleased with how quickly it comes together once the supporting tech exists, enabling fast iteration on platform layouts.

He comments on Malon’s/Brodude’s Kickstarter performance and observes that “personalized NPC/backer cameo rooms” seem like an extremely effective pledge strategy, with surprisingly high average pledge per backer (in his rough math).

biobak.summary: Kaze explicitly deprioritizes texture iteration because he expects Biobak to rework/replace much of Kaze’s current art pass anyway, implying a planned handoff/cleanup phase for visuals.

zeina.summary: Zeina contributes key visual identity elements for the level (notably a distinctive carpet texture/pattern), which Kaze showcases repeatedly as a defining part of the arcade/casino vibe.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I’ve heard before of people complaining that Germans never greet them back. And then it turns out that their greeting is, ‘Hello, how are you?’ And it’s like, bro, that’s not a greeting. That’s a question.
memorable_quotes.context: A long, character-revealing tangent about social norms and authenticity that doubles as an insight into Kaze’s impatience with performative rituals—mirroring his engineering mindset (don’t ask questions you don’t want real answers to).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.
memorable_quotes.context: A blunt justification for replacing remaining legacy code—part legal hygiene, part performance/maintainability—and a useful line for framing the project as both preservation and critique of SM64’s internals.

key_stories.title: Exploring a Steam-safe original-IP counterpart to RTYI
key_stories.summary: Kaze seriously considers a parallel product strategy: keep RTYI as the Nintendo-themed ROMhack, but also ship a largely similar, legally ownable game with original characters/assets for Steam distribution. This frames RTYI not only as a fan project, but as a stepping stone toward a commercial, independent game.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI’s Nintendo IP limits what can be sold/distributed, and friction/technical intimidation may keep broader audiences from trying a ROMhack.
key_stories.process: He proposes replacing Nintendo characters/branding, changing movement/mechanics enough to be functionally distinct, and using recomp/PC distribution to make it a simple purchase/download experience.
key_stories.outcome: No commitment yet; he describes it as hypothetical and dependent on interest, but he already has an original protagonist concept and sees clear marketing/distribution upside.
key_stories.key_quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own?

key_stories.title: Warp effect rewrite: removing Mario transparency to stop rendering breakage
key_stories.summary: A planned ‘fading warp’ animation caused the scene to break when Mario became transparent, likely due to how the project’s materials/render setup handle alpha. Kaze chooses a pragmatic engine-facing solution: avoid transparency entirely and use a scale-based transformation animation instead.
key_stories.challenge: Mario transparency is incompatible with the current material pipeline and introduces extra processing/flags that create bugs and overhead.
key_stories.process: He identifies the transparency pathway as the culprit, disables Mario’s ability to go transparent, and swaps the visual effect to a transformation-matrix scale animation (Mario compresses/disappears into the ground).
key_stories.outcome: A working, visually acceptable warp effect that avoids reintroducing transparency-related bugs and reduces unnecessary processing.
key_stories.key_quote: My life would be easier if we disabled the ability of Mario to go transparent.

key_stories.title: Lens flare bug traced to editing the wrong asset due to reverse level order
key_stories.summary: While tuning the sun/lens flare, parameter changes appeared to do nothing, creating a classic ‘the code is fine but reality disagrees’ debugging moment. The root cause was mundane but revealing: he was editing the wrong lens flare definition because the levels were authored in reverse order.
key_stories.challenge: Lens flare intensity stayed overly strong despite apparent configuration changes.
key_stories.process: He tests whether intensity is even applied, tries zeroing values, observes inconsistent behavior, then realizes the edits target the wrong instance/config because of the project’s level ordering.
key_stories.outcome: Fix found immediately once the correct asset/config is edited; he picks new target values and proceeds.

open_questions.topic: A potential Steam release as an original-IP version of RTYI
open_questions.context: Kaze suggests a second, legally ownable game that closely mirrors RTYI but replaces Nintendo IP and changes movement/mechanics, potentially leveraging recomp for distribution.
questions: What specific parts of RTYI would you change (movement, physics, characters, story framing) to make the original-IP version feel like its own game rather than a reskin?
Where do you draw the line between ‘90% the same content’ and ‘functionally a different game’—and who would help make that call (lawyers, publishers, peers, Nintendo risk tolerance)?
Would you want the Steam version to be a “definitive” version (more visuals/QoL), or intentionally different from the N64/ROMhack experience—and why?

open_questions.topic: Demo release strategy and avoiding schedule conflicts with other creators
open_questions.context: Kaze says the demo is coming ‘soon’ but likely not Christmas because another creator (‘Robot’) is releasing around then and he doesn’t want to overshadow it.
questions: Who is ‘Robot’ in your dev circle here, and what kind of relationship or etiquette governs not competing with each other’s releases?
How do you decide when RTYI is ready for a demo—what are your non-negotiable quality bars (stability, FPS, number of courses, polish)?

open_questions.topic: Playtesting philosophy: public demos vs repeated private testing
open_questions.context: Kaze argues demos are valuable for feedback, but says he often sends builds to a single person repeatedly as a targeted playtesting loop.
questions: Who is your ‘one-person’ playtester historically, and what makes them effective feedback for RTYI specifically?
What kinds of problems do you expect public demo players to surface that your tight private loop tends to miss (difficulty gating, onboarding confusion, hardware variance, softlocks)?
